timeline.bodyText: The test case here tests various functionalities at once. This also makes it pretty long. Would it be possible to split it into multiple test cases?
timeline.author: SaMuellerDLR

timeline.bodyText: Maybe this is a bit out of scope of the PR, but I dont like that we have the INDEX_NOT_EXISTENT declared at so many places (All list implementations, and their related test cases). I was thinking: Would it make sense to move the constant into the IBeanList interface and use it from there?
timeline.author: SaMuellerDLR

replies.bodyText: yes, i agree, should be moved.
replies.author: PhilMFischer

replies.bodyText: Just checked, it is actually already defined in AArrayInstanceList... I'm using this one now.
replies.author: franzTobiasDLR

timeline.author: SaMuellerDLR
SaMuellerDLR
SaMuellerDLR

timeline.bodyText: Why do we need to check equality via uuid instead of pi.equals(ca)
timeline.author: SaMuellerDLR

replies.bodyText:
Actually, I am a bit confused with this.
How can the uuid of some property instance be the same as the uuid of a category assignment?
Arent they (more or less) unrelated types?
replies.author: SaMuellerDLR

replies.bodyText:
This has been implemented in the lists to avoid issues in case objects get reloaded in between from the DLVM model.  Than you have different instances with the same UUID.
The question is, if the assumption back in the days was correct that there can be cases where we have this constellation of semantitcally same objects but as different instances. And we should think about the implications.
For me this is a more general question. And i guess this is taken from the other list implementations. Therefore i would accept it here and take the discussion to some other place.
replies.author: PhilMFischer

replies.bodyText: Yep, I simply adopted the way we handle this in the other property instance lists...
replies.author: franzTobiasDLR

timeline.bodyText: Why compare the uuids? Shouldnt the eReferencePropertyInstance be equal to the result of the array access?
timeline.author: SaMuellerDLR

replies.bodyText: No, the list creates a new java object. So basic equals implementation will fail.
replies.author: franzTobiasDLR

timeline.author: SaMuellerDLR
SaMuellerDLR

timeline.bodyText: Just wondering: Do we need the null check here or can the Set.Command.create deal with this case by itself?
timeline.author: SaMuellerDLR

replies.bodyText: Not sure, I'm doing that analog to how we handle it in the ReferencePropertyCellEditingSupport
replies.author: franzTobiasDLR
